references: While the application of differential privacy (DP) has been well-studied in cross-device federated learning (FL), there is a lack of work considering DP and its implications for cross-silo FL, a setting characterized by a limited number of clients each containing many data subjects. In cross-silo FL, usual notions of client-level DP are less suitable as real-world privacy regulations typically concern the in-silo data subjects rather than the silos themselves. In this work, we instead consider an alternative notion of silo-specific sample-level DP, where silos set their own privacy targets for their local examples. Under this setting, we reconsider the roles of personalization in federated learning. In particular, we show that mean-regularized multi-task learning (MR-MTL), a simple personalization framework, is a strong baseline for cross-silo FL: under stronger privacy requirements, silos are incentivized to federate more with each other to mitigate DP noise, resulting in consistent improvements relative to standard baseline methods. We provide an empirical study of competing methods as well as a theoretical characterization of MR-MTL for mean estimation, highlighting the interplay between privacy and cross-silo data heterogeneity. Our work serves to establish baselines for private cross-silo FL as well as identify key directions of future work in this area.

Existing approaches for differentially private FL are typically designed for client-level DP in that they protect the federated clients, such as mobile devices (â€œuser-levelâ€),
tasks in multi-task learning (â€œtask-levelâ€),
or data silos like institutions (â€œsilo-levelâ€), and DP is achieved by clipping and noising the client model updates.
While client-level DP is considered a strong privacy notion as all data of a single client is protected, it may not be suitable for cross-silo FL, where there are fewer clients but each hold many data subjects that require protection.
For example, when hospitals/banks/schools wish to federate patient/customer/student records, it is the people owning those records rather than the participating silos that should be protected. In fact, laws and regulations may mandate such participation in FL be disclosed publiclyÂ [96], compromising the privacy of the federating clients.

Related privacy settings.â€‚Past work on differentially private FL has concentrated on client-level DP and cross-device FL (e.g.Â [32, 74, 44, 34, 49, 48, 6]), and the application of DP in cross-silo FL, particularly where each silo defines its own DP targets for records of its own dataset, is relatively underexplored.
Privacy notions closest to ours first appeared inÂ [95, 56, 41, 109, 66, 51, 63].
In [95], each client adds its own one-shot noise onto its outgoing update, but in learning scenarios this provides client-level protection.
The works of [56, 66, 109, 41, 63] study analogous privacy notions, though they respectively focus on boosting utilityÂ [56], analyzing statistical ratesÂ [66], adapting FL to fğ‘“f-DPÂ [109, 25], applying security primitivesÂ [41], and learning a better global model; the aspects of heterogeneity, DP noise reduction, the personalization spectrum, and their interplay (e.g.Â Figs.Â 2 andÂ 5) were unexplored.
The work of [51] also considers a similar privacy notion, but the authors study a disparate trust assumption where DP noise is not added to local training/finetuning such that the final personalized models lack privacy guarantees.
We note that the trust model most suitable for private cross-silo FL may be application-specific; in this work, we focus on the setting where the outputs of the FL procedure (the personalized models) must remain differentially private.

Benchmark methods.
We consider several representative methods in the personalized FL literature beyond local training and FedAvgÂ [71]:
local finetuningÂ [99, 104, 19] (a simple but strong baseline for model personalization),
DittoÂ [57] (state-of-the-art personalization method),
MochaÂ [91] (personalization with task relationship learning),
IFCA/HypClusterÂ [33, 69] (state-of-the-art hard clustering method for client models), and the mean-regularized multi-task learning (MR-MTL) methodsÂ [30, 94, 38, 37] (which we analyze in SectionÂ 5).
For fair comparison under silo-specific sample-level DP, we align all benchmark methods on the total privacy budget by first restricting the total number of iterations over the local datasets and then account for any privacy overheads (in the form of necessary extra stepsÂ [57] or cluster selection for IFCA/HypClusterÂ [33, 69]).
Importantly, many other personalization methods can either be reduced to one of the above under convex settings (e.g.Â [46, 61]) or are unsuitable due to large privacy overheads (e.g.Â large factor of extra steps for [31]).

The case for mean-regularization.â€‚These considerations point to mean-regularized multi-task learning (MR-MTL) as one of the simplest yet particularly suitable forms of personalization.
MR-MTL has manifested in various forms in the literatureÂ [30, 105, 94, 38, 19, 44] with the key idea that a personalized model wksubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜w_{k} for each silo kğ‘˜k should be close to the mean of all personalized models wÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¤\bar{w} via a regularization penalty Î»/2â€‹â€–wkâˆ’wÂ¯â€–22ğœ†2superscriptsubscriptnormsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜Â¯ğ‘¤22\nicefrac{{\lambda}}{{2}}\|w_{k}-\bar{w}\|_{2}^{2} (see AlgorithmÂ A1 for a typical instantiation).
The hyperparameter Î»ğœ†\lambda serves as a smooth knob between local training and FedAvg, with Î»=0ğœ†0\lambda=0 recovering local training and a larger Î»ğœ†\lambda forces the personalized models wksubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜w_{k} to be closer to each other (â€œfederate moreâ€).
However, it is an imperfect knob as Î»â†’âˆâ†’ğœ†\lambda\to\infty may not recover FedAvg under a typical optimization setup as the regularization term may dominate the gradient step wk(t+1)=wk(t)âˆ’Î·â€‹(gt+Î»â€‹(wk(t)âˆ’wÂ¯(t)))superscriptsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜ğ‘¡1superscriptsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜ğ‘¡ğœ‚subscriptğ‘”ğ‘¡ğœ†superscriptsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜ğ‘¡superscriptÂ¯ğ‘¤ğ‘¡w_{k}^{(t+1)}=w_{k}^{(t)}-\eta\left(g_{t}+\lambda\left(w_{k}^{(t)}-\bar{w}^{(t)}\right)\right) where gtsubscriptğ‘”ğ‘¡g_{t} is the noisy clipped gradient, and MR-MTL may thus underperform FedAvg in high-privacy regimes that necessitate a large Î»ğœ†\lambda to mitigate DP noise (Fig.Â 3).

Navigating the emerging privacy-heterogeneity cost tradeoff.
In Fig.Â 5 we study the effect of the regularization strength Î»ğœ†\lambda on the model utility directly.
There are several notable observations:
(1) In both private and non-private settings, Î»ğœ†\lambda serves to roughly interpolate between local training and FedAvg.
(2) The utility at the best Î»âˆ—superscriptğœ†\lambda^{*} may outperform both endpoints. This is significant for the private setting since MR-MTL achieves an identical privacy guarantee as the endpoints.
(3) Moreover, the advantage of MR-MTL over the best of the endpoints are also larger under privacy.
(4) The value of Î»âˆ—superscriptğœ†\lambda^{*} also increases under privacy, indicating that the personalized silo models are closer to each other (i.e. silos are encouraged to â€œfederate moreâ€) for noise reduction.
We will characterize these behaviors in SectionÂ 6.
We also consider DittoÂ [57] in Fig.Â 5, a state-of-the-art personalization method that resembles MR-MTL and exhibits similar behaviors, to illustrate the effect of privacy overhead from its extra local training iterations.

When multiple records map to the same entity.
In this paper we studied the application of silo-specific sample-level differential privacy in cross-silo federated learning. While this is an important initial step towards a more suitable privacy model for cross-silo FL (in contrast to the commonly studied client-level DP model), we assume that each entity that requires privacy protection has at most one record (training example) across silos (e.g.Â a single patient has one medical record at a hospital).

VehicleÂ [26].â€‚The Vehicle Sensor dataset is a binary classification dataset containing K=23ğ¾23K=23 data silos.
Each silo (sensor) has acoustic and seismic measurements for a road segment, with each data point being a 100-dimensional feature vector describing the measurements when a vehicle passes through the road segment.
The goal is to predict between two predetermined types of vehicles.
We use a train/test split of 75%/25% following previous workÂ [91], yielding 872â‰¤nktrainâ‰¤1933872superscriptsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘˜train1933872\leq n_{k}^{\text{train}}\leq 1933 training examples on each client.
We use simple linear SVMs for classification followingÂ [91, 57].
It is a suitable dataset for cross-silo FL because the number of silos Kğ¾K is small while each silo has sufficient data to fit a good local model, as opposed to cross-device datasets such as FEMNISTÂ [16] where Kğ¾K is large but each silo has little data to learn a useful model. Moreover, we can use tight privacy budgets due to reasonably large local datasets (in terms of sufficiency for fitting a good local model) and SVMs (which are relatively noise-tolerant since decision boundaries only depend on support vectors). The dataset is accessible from the original authors.888https://web.archive.org/web/20110515133717/http://www.ece.wisc.edu:80/~sensit/

Google Glass Eating and Motion (GLEAM)Â [82].â€‚We also benchmark on the GLEAM dataset, a real-world head motion tracking dataset for binary classification. The motion data is collected with Google Glass, and the task is to classify the activity of the wearer (eating or not). There are in total K=38ğ¾38K=38 silos (wearers) and 27800 data points, with each silo containing 699â‰¤nkâ‰¤776699subscriptğ‘›ğ‘˜776699\leq n_{k}\leq 776 data points. Each data point is a 180-dimensional feature vector capturing head movement of the wearers.
Linear models yield reasonable utility on GLEAM and thus we use linear SVMs following previous workÂ [91]. Like Vehicle and School, this is a suitable dataset for cross-silo FL given a small Kğ¾K and relatively large local datasets.
Note that E.1 primarily serves to make results cleaner and easily interpretable (see SectionÂ E.5 for extensions). E.2 is mild since Gaussians have strong tail decay.
